title: Enhancing driver awareness of perceptual errors in approach speed judgments for road crossing and decisions at junctions.
abstractText:
Within many residential communities traffic speed is a major concern, yet a significant proportion of drivers admit to exceeding urban speed limits on their daily commutes. Despite public safety messages about the effects of exceeding speed limits, on an individual level these messages are often mediated by a driver's "optimistic bias" and their own perceived capability. Many drivers, when asked, feel they are significantly safer than the average driver. So when presented with a safety message many drivers will feel that they seldom make the mistake that is illustrated, or have the capability to cope with the situation.

What we propose to do is develop on-line "virtual reality" demonstrations of a range of errors that drivers can make in judging vehicle speed and pull-out time. These will highlight how, as humans, we are limited in our ability to judge speed of approach and as a result the speeding driver creates potential errors in other road users as s/he travels through urban environments. We have run a three month demonstration of this type in the Science Museum, but this project will develop a broader set of realistic demonstrations that can be distributed through road safety charities and campaigns.
